section.title: Passive Host State Translation
section.para: When &name-icinga; receives passive host checks from remote sources (i.e other &name-icinga; instances in distributed or failover setups), the host state reported by the remote source may not accurately reflect the state of the host from &name-icinga;' view. As distributed and failover monitoring installations are fairly common, it is important to provide a mechanism for ensuring accurate host states between different instances of &name-icinga;.
The image below shows a simplified view of a failover monitoring setup.

listitem.para: &name-icinga;-A is the primary monitoring server, and is actively monitoring all switches and routers.
&name-icinga;-B and &name-icinga;-C are backup monitoring servers, and are receiving passive check results from &name-icinga;-A
Both Router-C and Router-D have suffered failures and are offline.

section.para: What states are Router-C and Router-D currently in? The answer depends on which &name-icinga; instance you ask.

listitem.para: &name-icinga;-A sees Router-D as DOWN and Router-C as UNREACHABLE
&name-icinga;-B should see Router-C as DOWN and Router-D as UNREACHABLE
&name-icinga;-C should see both routers as being DOWN.

section.para: Each &name-icinga; instance has a different view of the network. The backup monitoring servers should not blindly accept passive host states from the primary monitoring server, or they will have incorrect information on the current state of the network.

Without translating passive host check results from the primary monitoring server (&name-icinga;-A), &name-icinga;-C would see Router-D as UNREACHABLE, when it is really DOWN based on its viewpoint. Similarly, the DOWN/UNREACHABLE states (from the viewpoint of &name-icinga;-A) for Router-C and Router-D should be flipped from the viewpoint of &name-icinga;-B.

note.para: There may be some situations where you do not want &name-icinga; to translate DOWN/UNREACHABLE states from remote sources to their "correct" state from the viewpoint of the local &name-icinga; instance. For example, in distributed monitoring environments you may want the central &name-icinga; instance to know how distributed instances see their respective portions of the network.

section.para: By default, &name-icinga; will not automatically translate DOWN/UNREACHABLE states from passive check results. You will need to enable this feature if you need and want it.
